item.title: Book Review: Getting Things Done
item.description:
A book on organization wouldn’t normally be especially gripping, but I just couldn’t put down David Allen’s Getting Things Done. The reason: instead of simply explaining the ‘how’ to making stuff in your life happen, he gives himself free reign to poetically suggest all the dreams and aspirations a productive life will enable you to accomplish.

Just imagine the serene sense of control you’ll have, effortlessly flitting from one task to another, making decisions with a quicksilver wit, and being as engaged with your family as your work life.

It’s a pretty mouth-watering prospect, if you ask me.

item.title: Book Review: The Art of Non-Conformity
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1385" align="alignright" width="118" caption="Clicking this image will take you to Amazon.com"][/caption]

Why jump off the bridge just because everyone else is doing it? You can step back from the bridge, turn around, and walk away into new adventures that had previously been only fleeting ideas. You can also help other people walk away from the bridge, or you can rewrite the rules the brought to the bridge in the first place. The possibilities are unlimited, but it all begins with the deliberate decision to think differently - Chris Guillebeau., The Art of Non-Conformity

It's been a while since I did a book review, as I've been reading several books at once. Nevertheless, I've finally managed to finish one, by fellow blogger and inspiration Chris Guillebeau of The Art of Non-Conformity. Chris is a self-described traveler and writer. He pays the bills by writing (which he can do from anywhere), and spends as much time as possible travelling the world with the ultimate goal of visiting every country. His book, The Art of Non-Conformity, provides readers with a glimpse of his unorthodox worldviews which, he maintains, are much more empowering and liberating than the traditional worldview we are taught to follow.

item.title: Book Review: The 80/20 Principle
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1194" align="alignright" width="104" caption="By Richard Koch"][/caption]

Here's an amazing, and disturbing, truth: 80% of anything that gets accomplished in your life comes from only 20% of your effort or time. 80% of your grades come from 20% of your studying. 80% of your productivity at work (and therefore the value of your income) comes from only 20% of actual time spent working. 80% of my quality writing is done in only 20% of the time I spend trying to write.

This idea - that most of what gets done is due to a minority of the causes - is the basis behind the 80/20 principle. The book, by Richard Koch, explains this concept and then illustrates what the 80/20 principle means for your real, everyday life. The subtitle, "the secret of success by achieving more with less," is a pretty enticing promise, and I believe that Koch delivers on this promise. This book will change the way you see the world, and should be read by anyone interested in achieving their potential.

item.title: Book Review: The Game, and Dating Advice for Men
item.description: With the recent popularity of Neil Strauss's book, The Game, there has been a lot of backlash against what some call 'dating advice for men' and others (usually women, to be fair) call 'coaching men to take advantage of and manipulate women.' The book is subtitled, Penetrating the Secret Society of Pickup Artists, and that pretty much sums up what it is about. The author undertook to learn the ways of pickup artists for a year, ended up becoming one of the greatest pickup artists in the world (according to an internal rating), developed his own system, and eventually stepped out. He then wrote a book about his experiences, triggering a massive outpouring of additional pickup methods, books, how-to's, workshops, dating coaching seminars, etc.

item.title: Book Review: I am Charlotte Simmons
item.description: Just finished Tom Wolfe's I am Charlotte Simmons, a disturbingly accurate depiction of modern American college life. The book is set in the fictional Ivy League University of Dupont, in Pennsylvania, and follows the first year of high school prodigy Charlotte Simmons. Charlotte, having won every award conceivable in high school, arrives at college with high expectations but finds herself overwhelmed by a world that cares more about social standing than academic achievement.

item.title: Book Review: Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
item.description: I recently completed the book Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance, by Robert M. Pirsig, which, contrary to its name, is not a book about Zen or motorcycle maintenance, except in a very roundabout way. The book is set in the motorcycle roadtrip of a father, the narrator, and his son, Chris, but the real meat of the book is contained in a series of chataquas, or talks, investigating a philosophical conundrum central to Western thought.
